sentences.sentence: The debate over the validity of Mary Ellen Turpel-Lafond's claim that she is a treaty Indian of Cree ancestry has shone a light on a question that does not have a clear answer: how does one verify Indigenous ancestry?As a country, Canada faces considerable challenges in addressing decades of wide-ranging discrimination against Indigenous people.

This includes the devastation caused to Indigenous families and communities by the Sixties Scoop and residential schools, which encouraged the assimilation of Indigenous culture into Euro-Canadian culture.One outcome of these programs was separating a multitude of people from their culture and language, leaving many Canadians removed or even unaware of their Indigenous heritage.

Further, the legal complexities of the Indian Act has made it challenging for generations of Indigenous people to return to their communities.Curious about how Canadians feel about verifying Indigeneity, our team at Leger surveyed 1,522 Canadians.
In the Canadian population, five per cent identify as Indigenous (First Nations, Metis or Inuit).

Our survey uncovered that an additional one-in-10 Canadians are uncertain whether they have Indigenous ancestry.Of that uncertain population, 40 per cent say they plan to investigate their identities.

This finding suggests the challenge of determining one's Indigenous ancestry may be a larger question for Canadians than one may initially think.While some people may explore their ancestry with genuine curiosity, the willingness to ask the question may be deterred by fears about wrongly appropriating Indigenous culture.

A considerable portion of Canadians (45 per cent) believe that false claims of Indigenous heritage are on the rise and speculate that the increase is likely attributed to fraudsters trying to take advantage of benefits (financial or otherwise) that would not be available to them as non-Indigenous people.We also asked whether this issue matters to Canadians, and our data shows that it does: 72 per cent of Canadians say questions around Indigenous ancestry are a serious issue and that they are bothered by false claims.
Four-in-10 agree that false claims of ancestry undermine progress toward truth and reconciliation.

Three-in-10 say falsely claiming to be of Indigenous heritage is serious and akin to someone fraudulently claiming to be professionally certified or holding a certain educational degree.So, if Canadians feel this is a serious issue, what should the recourse be?
That is where it gets interesting, particularly for governments.
Fifty-one per cent say there should be a Canadian-government-certified documentation process.

Twenty-one per cent support Indigenous nations certifying their citizens.To provide some teeth to enforcement, half of Canadians (51 per cent) say there should be a law in place that makes it a federal offence to fraudulently claim Indigenous heritage.

The responses from Indigenous and non-Indigenous respondents were in sync on this last point - a positive sign of alignment and a nod to the federal government to at least explore what new legislation could look like.However, juxtaposing Euro-Canadian governance upon Indigenous governance raises a new question: what would a "false-claims" law do?

Presumably, the goal would be to sort out bad actors claiming false identities, but how would Canada's 155-year-old system tackle this challenge?Indigenous and non-Indigenous Canadians may share a desire for transparency and consistency on the question of ancestry, but federal legislation on such matters may fly in the face of efforts to place greater control over matters directly affecting Indigenous affairs in the hands of Indigenous people.

It is a challenging problem that likely requires the first step toward action to be taken by Indigenous communities themselves.National PostAndrew Enns is an executive vice-president, and Heather Owen is a vice-president, at Leger(https://leger360.com/ ), the largest Canadian-owned market research and analytics company.
This column was written in collaboration with Daniel Voth, a Métis political scientist at the University of Calgary.

The survey data is from Leger's Omnibus Study, conducted from Nov. 18-20, 2022.Colby Cosh: Carrie Bourassa's evolving Indigenous identity a years-long con(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/colby-cosh-carrie-bourassas-evolving-indigenous-identify-a-years-long-con)Colby Cosh: Another prominent figure accused of faking Indigenous heritage(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/colby-cosh-another-prominent-figure-accused-of-faking-indigenous-heritage) !
